bibl.title: Letter from Laura Carter to Who's Who in America, A.N. Marquis & Company, October 7, 1925

div1.p: Laura Carter returns a biographical sketch of her father for Who's Who in America. [not enclosed] She notes that H.R. Carter recommended that Dunlap Pearce Penhallow and Thomas Manly Whedbee be included in the publication, and sends biographical information on Penhallow.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Carter to Who's Who in America, A.N. Marquis & Company, October 7, 1925
div1.opener:
Biographic
1/ Penhallow
2/ Whedbee
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
October 7, 1925.
Who's Who in America
A. N. Marquis & Company,
440 Dearborn Street South,
Chicago, Illinois, U. S. A.
Gentlemen:
div1.p:
I am returning herwith the sketch of my Father, Assistant Surgeon Gen-
eral Henry Rose Carter, as per your request.

My Father died on September 14, 1925, so I judge you will hardly
need the additional data I have supplied, and only need the sketch to
“check up” your material, not for publication in your next issue.

In connection with your very excellent and useful publication, my
Father intended this fall to bring to your attention the names of two
men, who, having done much of their work abroad, are better known there
than in their own country, and have not, so far, been included in “Who's
Who.” They are:
1/ Dunlap Pearce Penhallow, Surgeon, Author of the British “Military
Surgery” for the World War (an international compliment of a high order)
2/ Thomas Manly Whedbee, Civil Engineer and Explorer, whose last
work has been the location and building (as Chief Engineer) of the railroad
connecting Bolivia and the Argentine (a great piece of high altitude work)
Brief biographic sketches of both men are enclosed.
With best wishes for the continued success of your excellent book,
